intro: Cerinthe major subsp. major, commonly known as the common cerinthe, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters. The plant produces showy, spurred flowers that are typically blue or purple in color, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a slightly hairy texture. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it a versatile addition to gardens and natural habitats.
